The link in our bio will take you to a video that explains more about the attack and the controversies surrounding the incident.

Near the end of Tuesday night's Democratic primary debate, Anderson Cooper, referencing a quote from President Franklin Delano Roosevelt, asked the candidates whom they're most proud to claim as an enemy. Their answers were revealing about the kind of campaigns they're running. See 7 other charts that explain the #DemDebate via the link in our bio.

The first Democratic presidential debate of the 2016 campaign season begins tonight at 8:30 Eastern on CNN. If you're watching, we made bingo cards to make the #DemDebate a bit more fun. The link in our bio takes you to a second card.

Which countries are racking up the most Nobel Prizes? If you add up the awards by people’s country of birth, you end up with this map. The US comes out far on top, with 258 prizes. It's followed by the UK, Germany, and France. (Note that this data set doesn't include the roughly two dozen organizations that have won, including the 2015 Peace Prize for the Tunisian National Dialogue Quartet.)

Long before Twitter existed as a platform for politicians to instantly release their negative campaign messages, there was another means of campaigning on the fly: buttons. During the 1940 presidential campaign, Republican Wendell Willkie didn't pull any punches against incumbent (and third-term candidate) Franklin Roosevelt. The buttons kicked off a new age of campaigning, and they also symbolized the rancor of an unusual election that changed American politics forever.

These raw photos from 1969's Apollo 11 mission show the moon landing as you’ve never seen it before. The Project Apollo Archive is @nasa fan Kipp Teague's collection of previously unavailable pictures of NASA's space history, from pre-Apollo program to present. The entire collection of more than 12,000 photos is now on the project's website and on Flickr. In addition to commissioning special cameras for the Apollo 11 crew, NASA says that astronauts went to geologic sites in Nevada, Arizona, and Hawaii to practice photographing the rough, lunar-like terrain.

For 40 years, no one knew this woman discovered a malaria cure. Now Tu Youyou is one of three scientists to win this year's Nobel Prize for medicine for her finding of what has become a standard antimalarial treatment, artemisinin. The credit for this 84-year-old Chinese pharmacologist’s lifesaving achievement was uncovered just four years ago. In a statement, Tu called artemisinin "a gift for the world’s people from traditional Chinese medicine," and urged researchers to turn to herbs in the search for cures for infectious diseases. Read more about her incredible story via the link in our bio. Image: Xinhua News Agency

The Weeds is Vox's new policy podcast. Once a week, Ezra Klein, Matt Yglesias and Sarah Kliff will nerd out on the wonkiest policy topics they can think of. You can download the first episode in iTunes or listen via the link in our bio.

Obama challenged the media to compare gun and terrorism deaths. So we did. More than 10,000 Americans are killed every year by gun violence. By contrast, so few Americans have been killed by terrorist attacks since 9/11 that when you chart the two together, the terrorism death count approximates zero for every year except 2001. 
The point Obama is making is clear: We spend huge amounts of money every year fighting terrorism, yet are unwilling, at the national level, to take even minor steps (like requiring background checks on all gun sales nationally) to stop gun violence.

This is an illustration of the new medical billing code W56.22xA: Struck by an orca, initial encounter. For decades, medical providers have relied on ICD-9, a set of 14,000 medical codes to denote the various ailments and injuries they treat. On Thursday, the United States is switching to a much more granular set with 68,000 billing codes — including, yes, a billing code for patient struck by orca. A group called ICD-10 Illustrated has illustrated some of the most unlikely injuries. You can see more of their work via the link in our bio.

The Daily Show With Trevor Noah debuted Monday night. A first show can reveal plenty about a new series' priorities, and what it hopes to accomplish. Noah is not Jon Stewart, nor is he trying to be. Noah's tenure will be different from Stewart's by virtue of the two men being very different kinds of comics. Overall, it was a strong premiere with some telling moments.

Dany Paquete is a 26-year-old based in Havana who coordinates the collection and distribution of 1000GB of pirated media every week for consumption throughout the island of Cuba. The operation is a highly complex and professionally coordinated web of human runners. The only issue is that it’s completely illegal. Watch the full video via the link in our bio. Photo by @johnnywharris.

House Speaker John Boehner announced his resignation on Friday. As he tallied up his accomplishments, including major spending cuts and preventing most of the Bush tax cuts from expiring, this chart shows there was a lot he didn't get done: namely, enacting laws. Congress enacted a lower percentage of bills during Boehner's two full terms as House speaker than at any time in the previous 40 years.
Pope Francis became the first pontiff to deliver an address to a joint meeting of Congress on Thursday. Read the full text of his remarks via the link in our bio.

Pope Francis kicked off his visit to the US with a stop in Washington, DC and a meeting with President Obama at the White House before leading mass. What's next?

He'll address Congress on Thursday then fly to New York for two days. He'll arrive in Philadelphia on Saturday morning.

You can see his full schedule by following the link in our description.

Man buns. The hairstyle has existed throughout history, but it's safe to say the bun really came into its own after 2012. Lots of variables can affect a man bun's appearance, including: the size of the bun, the position of the knot, and the hair on the side of the head. Wondering if you should grow one? You must be the bun you wish to see in the world.
Viola Davis is the first black woman to win an Emmy for Outstanding Lead Actress in a drama. Her incredible acceptance speech shows how far Hollywood has to go.

Extra points in NFL games have become really boring. There were 1,230 extra point kicks last season. Only 8 of those were missed. This season, the extra point kick has been moved back from the 2-yard line to the 15-yard line. The full video can be found via the link in our bio.

Behold the 30-plus ingredients that make up Doritos Cool Ranch tortilla chips. Photographer Dwight Eschliman and author Steve Ettinger have taken a novel approach to food photography. Their new book, "Ingredients," shows how the processed foods you eat look nothing like food when deconstructed.

Are you watching the second #GOPDebate tonight? Play along with Vox's Bingo cards. The link in our bio takes you to a second card so you can play with a friend. The primetime debate starts at 8 pm Eastern on CNN.

Recent history has brought incredible progress for the LGBTQ community, as seen in the map on the left. But the lesser-known map on the right is important. It's still currently legal to fire LGBTQ people, kick them out of a store or business that serves the public, or evict them from housing because of their sexual orientation or gender identity. Watch the full video about the new frontier of LGBTQ rights, explained: https://youtu.be/YCjDnX-Xzhg

@nasa's newest set of Pluto photos taken by New Horizons shows the dwarf planet in unprecedented detail. This simulated view from 1,100 miles up is based on a composite of photos. Scientists still don't know what the dark regions are, or what chemical composition is responsible for their dark color.

Sarah A. Chrisman and her husband Gabriel love the Victorian era so much that they decided to live in it. "Every morning I wind the mechanical clock in our parlor. Each day I write in my diary with an antique fountain pen that I fill with liquid ink using an eyedropper. My inkwell and the blotter I use to dry the ink on each page before I turn it are antiques from the 1890s; I buy my ink from a company founded in 1670. My sealing wax for personal letters comes from the same company, and my letter opener was made sometime in the late Victorian era from a taxidermied deer foot.” The full essay is linked in our bio. Photos: Estar Hyo Gyung Choi

Cursive handwriting has been on its way out for two generations, long before texting became the preferred way for young people to communicate. When the SAT essay was first introduced, only 15 percent of high school students chose to write in cursive. Watch the video via the link in our bio to find out why 11 states are trying to save cursive from its inevitable death.

Boeing's Starliner spacecraft will ferry astronauts to and from the International Space Station starting in 2017 or 2018. The cone-shaped capsule is designed to be launched into orbit atop a rocket, carrying up to seven people into space. This Boeing graphic shows how the Starliner will work.

McDonald’s announced it will start serving all-day breakfast beginning October 6. The chain currently only serves breakfast from about 5 to 11 am, depending on the location. McDonald’s breakfast is apparently a subject that inspires much passion. Two of our writers explain – and debate – the changes, which you can read via the link in our bio. What do you think of the changes? Is an anytime Egg McMuffin a privilege or a right? (Image: @mcdonalds)

Wingdings, the font made entirely out of symbols, was created as a unique tool for the pre-Internet era. Think emojis, but with even more utility. Microsoft named the font after a combination an old printing term, "dingbat," with "Windows." Click the link in our bio to learn more about the font's fascinating history.

The Obama administration has announced that the peak formerly known as Mount McKinley will be known as #Denali, its traditional Native Alaskan name.

The change is widely supported by Alaskans, but has received backlash from politicians in McKinley's home state of Ohio.

This stunning image comes from @usinterior

Instagram just abandoned the square. You can now upload both portrait and landscape photos in the app. So how do you change the shape of a photo? Simply click on the button with the arrows in the bottom left corner of the screen. By offering new options, Instagram hopes to grow its user base. If you're not a fan of including new shapes, you'll have to deal with the consequences of Instagram changing your personal relationship to squares.

The National Park Service turns 99 today. Park entrance fees are waived for the day in celebration. If you can't make it out to a park, check out the gorgeous views from live streams and web cams across the country. (The link is in our bio.) These images via @nationalparkservice show conditions from Tuesday afternoon. Clockwise left to right: Acadia National Park, Shenandoah National Park, National Mall & Memorial Parks, Point Reyes National Seashore.

China's stock market has lost nearly 40 percent since June. Between June 2014 and June 2015, China's Shanghai Composite index rose about 150 percent, reaching a high of 5,166 on June 12. Then the bottom fell out of the market. In less than a month, it fell to 3,507 — a 32 percent decline.

A series of extraordinary interventions by the Chinese government helped stabilize the market and push it back up to 4,000. But the reprieve was short-lived. Last week, the market started plunging again. It closed at 3,210 on Monday.

Looking at a standard map of the U.S. can sometimes give you a skewed idea of where Americans live. This map scales states relative to their populations. One takeaway: The massive populations on the coasts — California's estimated population of 38,802,500 trounces Wyoming's 584,153.

Do you still have a childhood toy or blanket? Turns out you're not alone. A Travelodge poll of 6,000 British adults found that 35 percent of their adult guests tucked themselves in with a stuffed animal every night. Developmental behavioral pediatrician Dr. Barbara Howard told the New York Times that about 25 percent of young women heading to college reported having some sort of personal keepsake. Top left: Lauren Katz, top right: Melissa Bell, bottom left: Jeanne Poremba, bottom right: Charles Nusbaum

The Perseid meteor shower — the year's best — is tonight starting around 10 pm local time (regardless of your time zone). As Earth plows through a trail of dust and rock left behind by the comet Swift-Tuttle, tiny pieces of debris will enter our atmosphere and burn up, producing dazzling shooting stars. You'll be able to see as many as 50 of these meteors per hour — with the show aided by the low amount of light coming from the barely visible crescent moon. Image: David Kingman/Flickr
B-I-N-G-O! Play along with our #GOPDebate game.

Here's a view of the moon you don't usually see: the far side. @nasa released an incredible video today captured by the DSCOVR satellite. Why is this angle so rare? In roughy 27 days, the moon completes one orbit of Earth — and also rotates on its axis exactly one time. This means that the same side of the moon always faces Earth. (Image: @nasa)
As the US debates drug policy reforms and marijuana legalization, there's one aspect of the war on drugs that remains contradictory: some of the most dangerous drugs in the US are legal.

The wedding website The Knot found that the average wedding cost $31,000 in 2014. Why are weddings so expensive?

With most things people buy, they have a pretty good gauge on what they're getting for what they pay for. Wedding goods and services, however, are usually a once-in-a lifetime purchase. Add in that many wedding vendors don't post prices on their websites and you start to see why wedding planning can involve so much stress: the familiarity and transparency people rely on for other purchases just isn't there.

Watch via the link in our bio: "What I've learned about wedding prices from working in the industry."
Vox sat down with Bernie Sanders to discuss everything from unions to open borders to Zionism. Click the link in our bio to read or watch the full interview.

This 17th-century painting by Giovanni Stanchi offers a glimpse of a time before breeding changed watermelon forever. That fleshy interior is actually the watermelon's placenta, which holds the seeds. Before it was fully domesticated, that placenta lacked the high amounts of lycopene that give it the red color. Images: Christie Images LTD 2015/Shutterstock.

Did @nasa discover Earth 2.0? Maybe. Scientists have been searching for a potential Earth twin like #Kepler452b for decades. This NASA infographic shows the other planets discovered with the Kepler telescope. You can find details about NASA's newest discovery via the link in our bio.

Between 1990 and 2015, about 1.1 billion people have been lifted out of extreme poverty. That means that in just the past 25 years, a full seventh of humanity has been saved from terrible want. Visit the link in our bio for 10 other maps and charts that show the world is getting better all the time.

This morning, @NASA's #NewHorizons probe became the first spacecraft to ever visit Pluto. It passed within 7,750 miles of the dwarf planet — and for the first time in a generation, it's going to let us set eyes upon an entirely new world. Visit the link in our bio for all things #Pluto, from the beginning planning stages to what happens next.

For photographer Tammy Ruggles, being legally blind isn't a hindrance in her work — in fact, she says her low vision actually makes her art better. With the right technology and a shift in perspective, people can do things they thought impossible. Read her story at bit.ly/FirstPersonBlindPhoto 📷

Despite this progress, federal data shows that there were at least 9,997 central line catheter infections in 2013. Why do they happen at all? Experts believe these dangerous yet often preventable complications could be completely avoided. Here's how: http://bit.ly/1IN2aKX

More than 40 million stock trading accounts were opened in China between June 2014 and May 2015. In total, there are now more stock traders in China — 90 million — than members of the Communist Party.

This helps explain why China's leaders are panicking over the stock market's decline. A stock market crash will not only affect those 90 million people, it will affect their friends, family, and neighbors, and could trigger widespread anger at the government.
Read more joyless answers to history's corniest standup routines: http://bit.ly/1eDj5U8

A new study looks at how major state taxes — sales taxes, income taxes, and motor fuel taxes — have affected income inequality from 1984 to 2011. The differences are striking: While in some states, like Oregon, state taxes cut inequality significantly, in many Southern states like Tennessee, they actually exacerbated it.

Greece's debt-to-GDP ratio is an insane 172%. It's much higher than any other country in the Eurozone. But making matters worse is the fact that the financial markets no longer see Greece as debt-worthy. No one wants to lend to Greece at reasonable rates, and so Greece can't keep paying to service its current debts while carrying out basic government functions.

Oregon now lets you legally possess more marijuana than any other state. The Beaver State joins the ranks of Colorado, Washington state, Alaska, and Washington, DC, all of which have legalized marijuana possession. But only the four states allow or will allow legal sales, while Congress prevented DC from doing so.

President Barack Obama's approval ratings have jumped to their highest point in recent years. According to a recent CNN/ORC poll, about 50 percent of respondents expressed approval of the president. These numbers constitute Obama's highest marks in this poll since May 2013.
The Supreme Court, in a 5-4 decision, sided with the state of Oklahoma in a ruling that allows states to continue using experimental lethal injection drugs.

Today's Supreme Court decision to legalize same-sex marriage should take effect immediately, or close to it, in the 13 states that don't already all gay couples to marry. Some states could drag their feet by requiring lower federal courts to lift stays or affirm the ruling. #LoveWins #SCOTUSMarriage

The Supreme Court just legalized same-sex marriage across the U.S in a 5-4 decision. The ruling means that same-sex marriage is legal in all 50 states, and states will soon have to grant marriage licenses to all same-sex couples. #LoveWins #SCOTUSMarriage

The King v. Burwell decision means that the Affordable Care Act stands unchanged. The government will continue subsidizing coverage for 6.4 million Americans. "Congress passed the Affordable Care Act to improve health insurance markets, not to destroy them," Chief Justice John Roberts wrote in the court's opinion.

Heart disease and cancer are far and away the leading causes of death in America. But globally the picture is more complicated. It's worth stressing that "cause of lost years of life" and "cause of death" aren't identical. For example, deaths from preterm births may cause more lost years of life in a country than deaths from heart disease even if heart disease is the leading cause of death. Deaths from preterm births amount to many decades of lost life, whereas heart disease tends to develop much later on.

Now that South Carolina's Governor has called for the removal of the Confederate flag from Capitol grounds, the flag issue may be off the table for the 2016 Republican presidential contenders. But not before many of the GOP candidates — even some who hinted at opposing the flag — showed their allegiance to state sovereignty.

Despite signs of decline in gun ownership, the US still has a huge number of private guns. In 2012, Americans owned an estimated 270 million guns, almost 42 percent of the total number of civilian-owned guns on the entire planet.

Pope Francis is urging the world to act on climate change and the environment. In a 184-page letter, he calls on the world's nations — especially rich nations — to curtail fossil fuel use, revamp their economic systems, and alter their lifestyles in order to avoid "unprecedented destruction of ecosystems."

Here's how the rich rate social policy preferences in comparison to the general public. The top item on rich people's list of concerns? The deficit. The lowest? Climate change. Visit the clickable link in our bio to see more comparisons.

How much does your race matter when it comes to having your voice heard in politics? How about your gender? Your income? Answer: a lot, according to University of Chicago law professor Nicholas Stephanopoulos. 
Among the demographics he looked at — including racial minorities and low-income individuals — women have the least influence on policy at both the state and federal level. In cases where there's major disagreement between men and women, the chance of a policy taking effect falls the more it's supported by women, and it falls dramatically: from 80 percent to about 10 percent.
The US Census has been counting African Americans as a separate race since 1820. But the way it's categorized African Americans, and what it's called them, has changed constantly.

The US wastes $162 billion of food each year, and more than 49 million Americans live in a state of food insecurity. Former Trader Joe's President Doug Rauch wants to change that. This month, he opened a not-for-profit grocery store in Boston in hopes of giving the working poor healthier options and fast-food prices.

Student debt has skyrocketed in the past few years. About 70 percent of students earning bachelor's degrees in 2013 had loans; on average, they owed more than $30,000 at graduation, according to the Institute for College Access and Success. Read more about Elizabeth Warren's plan for debt-free college via the link in our bio.

The existence of the Entourage movie has been met with a persistent, entirely fair question: why? Why does this TV show get a follow-up movie, when so many other great TV shows — even big, hit TV shows — are left to languish? The combination of factors is pretty unique — and essentially suited only to Entourage. Read 9 possible reasons via the clickable link in our bio.

The American party system is unusual in the democratic world for having only two parties represented in the national legislature while containing many more citizens than a typical country. In Canada, there are five parliamentary parties representing a population that's about a tenth the size of America's. Tiny Israel has 10 parties in its Knesset.

Bernie Sanders is like a third party candidate who just happens to be running inside the Democratic Party. He's not speaking the bland, lowest common denominator model of most presidential candidates. Read more about how he's winning the Internet and changing the conversation via clickable link in our bio.
This is standard advice for referring to people's gender identity: respect their wishes.
In our recent interview with Bill Nye, he explains why scientific illiteracy drives him crazy. A clickable link is in our bio.

Researchers at McGill University polled 3,377 students, staff, and faculty on the forms of transportation they used to get to the downtown Montreal campus, as well as their levels of satisfaction with various aspects of their commutes (such as travel time, comfort, safety from traffic, safety from crime, unwanted attention, cost, and waiting time). When the researchers combined all the numbers, they found two rough tiers of overall commuting satisfaction: commuters who walked, biked, or took the intercity train, and commuters who drove, or took the bus or local metro.

The game of Life is more than 150 years old, and its early incarnations were very, very different. The goal wasn't to be a millionaire, but simply to live a good life. And that included the risk of suffering some incredibly depressing consequences.
The US released a trove of bin Laden's books and papers. Here's what's in them.

This is David Letterman's first-ever Top Ten List. When his show first aired on September 18, 1985, the list wasn't just a collection of halfhearted zingers — it was far more conceptually bizarre than what we see on the show today. Letterman will give his last list tonight.

When Americans are asked to name a living scientist, the second-most common response — after Stephen Hawking — is Neil deGrasse Tyson. We spoke with him about his wish list for NASA's space exploration program, his thoughts on extraterrestrial life, his predictions for the long-term future of the human race, and his plans for his TV show. Check it out via the clickable link in our bio.

A 2013 survey from the National Gang Intelligence Center found that about 2.5 percent of gang members nationwide are in outlaw motorcycle gangs.

Police still consider them to be more threatening than their small numbers might suggest. About 10 percent of jurisdictions said they considered the motorcycle gangs a serious threat.
Action sequences/the number of vehicles crashed in Mad Max movies, in one chart.

Since 2002, NASA's Aqua Satellite has been orbiting Earth, taking thousands of high-resolution photos of our planet in order to help scientists better understand our water cycle and weather.

Recently, NASA compiled all this data to produce the gorgeous map above — a map of the average cloud cover everywhere on Earth for the last 13 years.

Dark blue areas see very little cloud cover. White areas are cloudy almost all the time. Image: @nasa Earth Observatory.

Train travel is much safer than other forms of travel.

The most recent comparison study, conducted in 2013 by economist Ian Savage, compared fatality rates for several different forms of travel in the US.

The number of rail deaths from year to year ranges widely (because many can happen in large, sporadic accidents), but between 2000 and 2009, a person was about 17 times more likely to die while traveling in a car, compared to a train, for the same distance.

In the US (and a few other countries that conventionally write dates as MM/DD/YY), every date this week is a palindrome. A week of palindromes isn't all that rare. Since 2011, each year has had a streak of 10 straight dates that can be written as a palindrome. It'll be in June next year (because June is the sixth month and it's 2016) and will keep happening until 2020.
The most important factor in victory of the Allies over the Axis powers in World War II: economics. See 42 maps that explain World War II via clickable link in bio.
One nation under God, mapped.

Little Italy and Canton are two nearby neighborhoods in Baltimore. It's about 1.5 miles from one to the other, either seven minutes by car or a half-hour walk.

But for a newborn baby, the neighborhoods couldn't be further apart. Kids born in Little Italy are more than 10 times as likely to die before their first birthday as those born in Canton.

Want to know what sets Bernie Sanders apart from Hillary Clinton? Look at their donors. Bernie Sanders' top donors are unions. Hillary Clinton's top donors are banks. (Source: OpenSecrets.org, screenshot from Bombed.)

More than than three-quarters of American workers now drive to work alone, while another 10 percent still ride in carpools. The number of people biking or taking public transportation might be rising very slightly, but combined they still only account for about 5.5 percent of commuters. How do you get to work?

Our tumblr is up and running! 
Have you checked it out? 
vox.tumblr.com

The World Happiness Report asked respondents to imagine the best possible life for them and then rank their current lives on a 0 to 10 scale, relative to that best life. Important variables that determine national happiness: 
Social support
Healthy life expectancy
Freedom
Generosity
Government corruption

In April 1995, the Hubble Space Telescope — which was launched into orbit exactly 25 years ago — took its most iconic image: the Pillars of Creation. These gigantic towers of dust and gas, 7,000 light years away, are named because the immense force of gravity causes them to condense into clumps of matter that will become new star systems.

Visit our site for an in-depth view of the Pillars of Creation.

Image credit: @nasa/ESA/Hubble Heritage Team (STScl/AURA)/J.Hester, P. Scowen (Arizona State U.)

You may have already heard of the Great Pacific garbage patch — a giant patch of plastic trash that's accumulated in a swirling subtropical gyre in the northern Pacific Ocean. In July 2014, we learned that there are at least five of these floating garbage patches around the world.

One recent study in Science Magazine calculated that between 5 million and 13 million metric tons of our plastic waste makes it into the ocean each year. 
Map: Cozar et al., 2014.

Sorry, Pluto. You're really not a planet. The simplest reason is Pluto's tiny size, both in diameter and mass. Based on this chart of the smaller planets and other objects we've found in the solar system, it seems more intuitive to group Pluto with these smaller objects than with bigger planets.

Marijuana is believed to have originated in southeast Asia, around modern China. Chinese folklore credits Emperor Shen Nung, who's often referred to as the father of Chinese medicine, with discovering it's medical uses. Check out 24 charts and maps that explain marijuana on our site.

Between 2009 and 2013, Medicare spent $316 billion less than expected due to slower-than-expected health care cost growth.

To underscore just how much money $316 billion is, we stacked it up against other things the federal government spends money on. The savings would be enough to cover federal spending on the Children's Health Insurance Plan, Amtrak, and the National Park Service more than twice over.

The federal government keeps a live ticker of how many people are on government websites, and which pages are getting the most traffic. In the week before Tax Day, the IRS site had 21 million hits — way ahead of even the perennially popular Weather.gov. The most popular page on the IRS site? "Where's My Refund?" Source: analytics.usa.gov, as of 11 am, April 15.

Let's consider a man and a woman getting started saving for retirement. Let's assume they start saving at age 25. The median 25- to 34-year-old man earns $40,000, according to the Education Department, compared with $35,000 for a woman. A Bankrate retirement calculator shows that given those early salaries, the savings difference at retirement is nearly $200,000. Find out more about our calculations and the gender wage gap in general on our site. #EqualPayDay

As the world's population soars past 7 billion, the pressure for cropland is growing. This is the state of Rondônia in western Brazil, one of the most deforested parts of the Amazon. In 1978, 2 percent of the state's rainforest had been cleared. By 2008, that was up to 34 percent — an area the size of West Virginia. 
See 15 before-and-after images that show how we're transforming the planet on our site. Images: @nasa, Images of Change.

An analysis of the available FBI data by Vox's Dara Lind shows that US police kill black people at disproportionate rates: black people accounted for 31 percent of police shooting victims in 2012, even though they made up just 13 percent of the US population.

Although the data is incomplete, since it's based on voluntary reports from police agencies around the country, it highlights the vast disparities in how police use force.

About 4 in 10 Americans don't identify strictly as "pro-life" or "pro-choice." Abortion usually gets framed as a two-sided debate. But while abortion views are strongly held, personal factors and situations influence how each individual thinks about the issue. Our poll reveals that Americans aren't as divided on abortion as it seems.
Happy Voxiversary! One year ago today we had our first full day publishing content on Vox.com.

Claw machines are rigged in a surprisingly clever way. This is a section from the manual for Black Tie Toys' Advanced Crane Machine. The machine's owner can fine-tune the strength of the claw beforehand so that it only has a strong grip a fraction of the time people play. The owner can also adjust the "dropping skill." That means that on a given number of tries, the claw will drop a prize that it's grabbed before it delivers it to you.

Kit-Kats are ludicrously popular in Japan. There are 200 insane flavors, including red bean toast, soy sauce, blueberry fromage, and many others. Why so many? Some manufacturers say the country's unique retail system deserves credit. Because there are more than 40,000 retail stores competing for customers, manufacturers create many new, limited-edition products to grab the shelf space necessary to drive sales. (Image via Flickr user Alan Teo.) For more snacks that explain our delicious world, visit the clickable link in our bio.

The Eiffel Tower opened to the public 126 years ago, on March 31, 1889. Today, it's an icon. At the time, the project created a clash between France's artistic and industrial voices. The critique from artists was so scathing that Gustave Eiffel himself eventually felt the need to respond.

This map created by Branden Rischel shows only the world's time zones — without any of the land underneath. It highlights just how unusual these artificial boundaries can be. 
The idea for a worldwide time-zone system gained currency at the International Meridian Conference in 1884. By the 1900s, the idea was widely accepted and practiced.

Balmy Florida and booming North Dakota were two of the most popular places for people to move in 2014. 
This map, made from census data compiled and mapped by @trulia, shows that weren't any huge, state- or region-wide trends in where Americans moved last year; most states have some pockets that lost people and some that gained people. 
Hat tip to Jed Kolko.

Marijuana legalization in 2012 didn't eliminate racial disparities in Colorado's pot arrests. A new report by the pro-legalization Drug Policy Alliance found that marijuana-related charges dropped by more than 90 percent between 2010 and 2014. 
The penalties that remained — for illegal distribution, public use, and possession in excess of one ounce — were disproportionately enforced against black Coloradans. The marijuana arrest rate for black people in 2010 and 2014 was 2.4 times the rate for white residents, according to the report.

In 2013, the government's Office of Personnel Management accidentally sent $84.7 million in payments to retired federal workers who'd already died — slightly less than in the previous few years.

By contrast, the New Horizons spacecraft, launched in 2006 and due to reach Pluto this summer, cost a total of $700 million, or $77.8 million per year.

To learn about six other surprising things the government spends more money on than space exploration, visit our site. (Clickable link in bio.)

This subway map of the National Park System, made by @SierraClub, makes it easy to see how America's parks are distributed. The NPS was created in 1916, and as a result, it favors the West, which was less developed at the time, had more space and was easier to claim for parkland.

Single studies often contradict one another — such as the research on foods that prevent cancer. The truth can be found somewhere in the totality of the research, but we report on every study in isolation underneath flip-flopping headlines. (Red wine will add years to your life one week, and kill you quicker the next.) This is why you shouldn't believe that exciting new medical study.

Surveys of 374,000 adults give us the clearest picture yet of where LGBT Americans live. New analysis by Gallup of the 50 largest metropolitan areas shows that more LGBT people live in the West and are less likely to reside in the South and Midwest.

In the 21st century, there will be 224 solar eclipses. A few lucky folks in the Faroe Islands and Svalbard will see something rarer on Friday: a total solar eclipse, in which the moon completely covers the sun. The next time Americans will get the chance to see a total eclipse will be in August 2017.

A huge solar storm created dazzling auroras worldwide this week. Bright auroras are normally only visible close to the poles — in places like Alaska or Iceland. On Tuesday, people could see the lights as far south as New York and New Jersey. This photo of the lights over the still-frozen Lake Ontario by Flickr user darosenbauer was taken in Western New York.

The average Wall Street bonus totaled nearly $173,000 in 2014. The $28.5 billion that employees took home last year is more than double the minimum wage earnings figure. This chart shows more of the jaw-dropping comparisons you can draw to the Wall Street bonus pool.

This chart shows one way Americans really stand out: their positive attitudes. According to Pew data, people in the developing world were generally more likely than their developed world peers to give a more positive assessment of their day. But Americans were a major outlier. (Credit: Pew Research Center)

Today's date is 3/14/15 (at least in the US and a few other countries that write dates that way), which matches up nicely with the first five digits of pi, the ratio of every circle's circumference to its diameter: 3.1415.

Here are the states that serve the most local food at school. In the Northeast, almost all school districts are on board with the farm-to-table movement — but the rest of the country is pretty far behind. (Credit: @usdagov)

The Apollo missions landed humans on the moon six times. But the truth is that we've barely explored it. 
This map — showing the Apollo 11 landing site superimposed on a baseball diamond — shows just how little of the moon we've seen firsthand.
The difference between toys for boys and girls, in one flowchart. (H/t to Twitter user @lindaperlstein.)

President Barack Obama spoke in Selma, Alabama to commemorate the 50th anniversary of Bloody Sunday, the day civil rights protesters in the state were brutally beaten by police officers when they tried to march in support of voting rights.

Every year, millions of Americans get sick from the things they eat and drink. But it's not always the foods you'd expect that poison people.

According to an estimate from the CDC, fruits and vegetables poison more Americans than beef and chicken combined.

A recent CDC study of health education programs looks at what's being taught in sex education classes across the US.

Right now, nine states require that sexual education classes be inclusive of sexual orientation. Three states — Alabama, South Carolina and Utah — require that teachers tell students about the health hazards of homosexuality.
This chart of vocabulary used by Shakespeare v. rappers is an interesting look at how English has changed. Credit: Designer Matt Daniels

The King v. Burwell case centers on one big question: does the federal government have the legal authority to help Healthcare.gov enrollees pay for health insurance coverage?

If the answer is no, the subsidies go away — and health insurance gets a lot more expensive.
This chart shows 130 years of facial hair trends in London. You could call it "The Rise of the Razor."
The Dutch Embassy doesn't appreciate people comparing Amsterdam to Washington, DC just because the District legalized marijuana. The Netherlands fired back with this infographic.
This XKCD cartoon is the simplest explanation of the color-changing dress. Your interpretation of the dress depends on the way your eye perceives the light around it.

Sometimes you can't quite describe how you feel. There's probably a word for whatever emotion it is — in a different language. Graphic designer @anjanaiyer beautifully illustrates foreign words with no English translation. (Check out more on our site.)

This is Rosa Parks' recipe for "Featherlite" pancakes. To mark the late civil rights icon's birthday, the Library of Congress opened up a collection of her letters, photographs and notes for speeches. (Credit: Library of Congress)

At the national level, there seems to be a political split over which party supports mandatory vaccinations — and which wants parents to have a say in the matter. But when you look at state policies — which states allow more exemptions, and which don't let parents opt out — the political divide disappears.
It's 2015 and the government is selling $28 CD-ROMs of the federal budget. The whole proposal is available to download for free and has been for years.
Given the NFL's huge popularity, there's something surprising about the average NFL game: very little of it involves people playing football.
